Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the Court may modify custody orders upon a finding of a material and substantial change in circumstances that affects the best interests of the children.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209C, \u00a7\u00a7 3.proposition: This case falls under the jurisdiction of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts Probate and Family Court pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209C, §§ 3 and 10.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 223, \u00a7 1 and ch.raw_text: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 223, § 1 and ch. 223A, § 2
Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 223, \u00a7 1 and ch.proposition: Venue is proper in Middlesex County under Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 223, § 1 and ch. 223A, § 2.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 265, \u00a7 13A.proposition: This individual has a criminal record for assault and battery in violation of Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 265, § 13A, as well as a history of being subject to a restraining order under Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209A.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209A.proposition: This individual has a criminal record for assault and battery in violation of Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 265, § 13A, as well as a history of being subject to a restraining order under Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209A.

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 597.proposition: The Massachusetts Appeals Court has held that courts must consider exposure to violence as a significant factor in custody determinations.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 597.support_reasoning: The quoted opinion is from the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court, not the Appeals Court, so it cannot itself stand for what “the Massachusetts Appeals Court has held.” Substantively, the SJC does hold that courts must make explicit findings and consider the impact of domestic violence on children in custody determinations, but attributing that holding specifically to the Appeals Court is inaccurate. Thus, while the case supports a closely related principle, it does not support the proposition as phrased.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 597.relevant_excerpt: “We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below ‘fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.’ … The Probate Court failed to consider the special risks to the child in awarding custody to a father who had committed acts of violence against the mother. … Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child … will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (20.raw_text: *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (2012) ("Courts must consider a child's need for security and stability when reviewing parenting plans.")
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (20.proposition: A neighbor called the police during a loud and aggressive argument in Defendant's household while the children were present, further evidencing an unsafe and unstable environment.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (20.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a neighbor calling the police during a loud and aggressive argument in the defendant’s household as evidence of an unsafe and unstable environment, which is typically relevant in criminal or child-welfare contexts. Hunter v. Rose is a family-law custody and parentage case focusing on best-interests, stability, and parental alienation; it does not mention police involvement, neighbor reports, domestic disturbances, or similar facts. While the case does discuss instability and harm to a child, it cannot be cited as authority for the specific proposition about a neighbor’s police call evidencing an unsafe and unstable home environment.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (20.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that disrupting the attachment a child has to a parent and behaving in ways designed to alienate a child from that parent causes harm that can be long term, and if sole physical custody must be awarded because of geographic distance between parents, ‘it is in the best interests of a child to be in the sole custody of the parent who can support the involvement of both parents rather than with the parent who alienates the child from the other parent.’ Moreover, she found that Hunter was entirely supportive of Jill’s relationship with Rose….”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (.raw_text: *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (2006) ("A material and substantial change in circumstances must directly implicate the child’s best interests.")
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (.proposition: These circumstances pose a substantial risk to the children’s emotional and physical well-being, which constitutes a material change in circumstances warranting modification of the current order under Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208, § 28, and relevant case law.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns what constitutes a “material change in circumstances” justifying modification under Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208, § 28, specifically tying that concept to substantial risk to children’s emotional and physical well-being. Mason v. Coleman is a removal case under § 30, applying a best-interests standard to a proposed relocation in a joint physical custody context; it does not analyze or define “material and substantial change in circumstances” under § 28. The opinion never links substantial risk or harm to the § 28 material-change threshold, so it does not provide authority for the proposition claimed.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (.relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that “[a] minor child of divorced parents … shall not … be removed out of this Commonwealth … without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.” “The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.” Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985). … “[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.” Adoption of Vito, 431 Mass. 550, 566 (2000).

*Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 616.raw_text: *Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 616 (1987) (acknowledging the court’s authority to impose conditions necessary to protect a child’s welfare)
*Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 616.proposition: An order barring Defendant’s partner from being present during Defendant’s parenting time.
*Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 616.support_reasoning: The opinion is about jurisdiction, custody, property division, alimony, and fraudulent conveyance; it does not discuss, approve, or impose any condition limiting a parent’s parenting time based on the presence of a partner or companion. The only mention of the father’s partner is in describing his living situation and finances, not as a subject of visitation or custody conditions. Thus, this case does not provide authority for an order barring a defendant’s partner from being present during parenting time.
*Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 616.relevant_excerpt: Finally, we note the judge’s stated intention of making contact with his counterpart in the Bielefeld Family Court to construct a joint order on visitation. It is the judge’s laudable desire that Anthony have reasonably liberal visitation rights which may be exercised both in Germany and this country. We hope that an order with complementary terms can be arranged by the two courts which will allow both parents maximum time with their children in a cooperative effort to rear them.

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 842 (2.proposition: If Defendant refuses or is unable to ensure that his partner does not have contact with the children, Plaintiff requests that all parenting time be supervised by a neutral third party approved by the Court.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 842 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns standards for initial custody determinations for unmarried parents and the relationship between the statutory ‘best interests of the child’ standard and G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a). It does not discuss supervised parenting time, conditions related to a parent’s partner having contact with the children, or requirements that visitation be supervised by a neutral third party. Therefore, it provides no authority for the specific proposition about supervised parenting time if a parent refuses or is unable to prevent a partner’s contact with the children.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 842 (2.relevant_excerpt: In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is “best for the child” is firmly rooted in American history... General Laws c. 209C, § 10 (a), which was enacted in 1986, reflects this trend... The statute gives direction to the judge’s consideration of a child’s “best interests” by “evincing a general intent on the part of the Legislature to maintain the bonds between the child and her caregiver.” Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 244 (2000).

*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the Court may modify custody orders upon a finding of a material and substantial change in circumstances that affects the best interests of the children.
*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly interprets G.L. c. 208, § 28, stating that after a divorce the court may modify its earlier custody judgment when there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances and the modification is necessary in the best interests of the children. The court applies that standard to criticize the trial judge’s failure to recognize the mother’s remarriage as such a change, thereby affirming the legal proposition described.
*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.relevant_excerpt: “He concluded from this that any change in circumstances occurred prior to the divorce, and therefore did not justify a modification. His ruling is inconsistent with G. L. c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1993, c. 460, § 60 (‘Upon a complaint after a divorce … , the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children’).”

*Wilkins v. Wilkins*, 324 Mass. 261, 263.raw_text: *Wilkins v. Wilkins*, 324 Mass. 261, 263 (1949) (holding that a child’s welfare is the primary consideration in custody determinations)
*Wilkins v. Wilkins*, 324 Mass. 261, 263.proposition: The presence of an individual with a documented history of violence and instability in Defendant’s household constitutes a material change that directly affects the safety, security, and best interests of the children.
*Wilkins v. Wilkins*, 324 Mass. 261, 263.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on whether parents are statutorily “unfit” and emphasizes that the welfare of the child is the paramount consideration in custody and guardianship decisions. It does not address the concept of a “material change” in circumstances, nor does it discuss the presence of an individual with a documented history of violence or instability as a specific factor. Thus, while it supports the general best-interests standard, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about a violent/unstable individual in a household constituting a material change affecting the children’s safety and security.
*Wilkins v. Wilkins*, 324 Mass. 261, 263.relevant_excerpt: “In determining whether parents are unfit, the most important consideration is whether the welfare of the child would be served by custody in them or in a guardian. … The welfare of the child would be served by leaving her where she is.”

*Ginsberg v. Ginsberg*, 429 Mass. 565, 5.proposition: Moreover, the Court has broad discretion to impose safeguards necessary to ensure the children’s safety.
*Ginsberg v. Ginsberg*, 429 Mass. 565, 5.case_name: Prudential Insurance Co. of America v. Commissioner of Revenue
*Ginsberg v. Ginsberg*, 429 Mass. 565, 5.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns Massachusetts retaliatory insurance tax calculations and related equal protection and procedural issues. It does not involve family law, child custody, or any discussion of a court’s discretion to impose safeguards for children’s safety. The cited case name (Ginsberg v. Ginsberg) also does not match the provided text (which is Prudential’s tax case), confirming that this opinion does not support the stated proposition.
*Ginsberg v. Ginsberg*, 429 Mass. 565, 5.relevant_excerpt: No portion of the provided opinion text discusses child custody, children’s safety, or judicial safeguards; the entire opinion addresses the computation and constitutionality of retaliatory insurance premium taxes.

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: Furthermore, Plaintiff’s allegations demonstrate sufficient cause for modification consistent with the Court’s analysis in *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985), which emphasizes the importance of conducting a holistic review of the child’s living environment and primary caretaker's ability to provide a safe and nurturing home.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The proposition characterizes Yannas as emphasizing a holistic review of the child’s living environment and primary caretaker’s ability to provide a safe and nurturing home. In fact, the cited portion of Yannas focuses on the removal/relocation standard (“real advantage”) and how to determine a child’s best interests in that context, including the custodial parent’s reasons for moving, the impact on visitation, and the child’s overall quality of life. While the opinion does mention the custodial parent’s role, it does not specifically frame the analysis around a holistic review of the living environment or safety/nurturing in the way the proposition suggests, nor does it concern modification of a prior order.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”
